section.title: Hardware configuration
section.para: Because there are several variations of hardware, it is up to you to verify that the hardware is configured properly.

listitem.para: Only Intel based compute nodes are supported. There is no DPDK available for AMD-based CPUs.
PCI-PT must be enabled for the NIC that will be used with DPDK.
When using Intel Niantic and the igb_uio driver, the VT-d must be enabled in the BIOS.
For DL360 Gen9 systems, the BIOS shared-memory .
Adequate memory must be available for usage.
Hyper-threading can be enabled but is not required for base functionality.
Determine the PCI slot that the DPDK NIC(s) are installed in to determine the associated NUMA node.

Only the Intel Haswell, Broadwell, and Skylake microarchitectures are supported. These architectures are found in DL360 Gen9 and Gen10 hardware. Intel Sandy Bridge is not supported which is found in DL360 Gen8 hardware.
Only &sle_repo; compute nodes are supported.

If a NIC port is used with PCI-PT, SRIOV-only, or PCI-PT+SRIOV, then it cannot be used with DPDK. They are mutually exclusive. This is because DPDK depends on an OvS bridge which does not exist if you use any combination of PCI-PT and SRIOV. You can use DPDK, SRIOV-only, and PCI-PT on difference interfaces of the same server.

There is an association between the PCI slot for the NIC and a NUMA node. Make sure to use logical CPU cores that are on the NUMA node associated to the NIC. Use the following to determine which CPUs are on which NUMA node.

listitem.para: If you do not specify a driver for a DPDK device, the igb_uio will be selected as default.
DPDK devices must be named dpdk<port-id> where the port-id starts at 0 and increments sequentially.
Tenant networks supported are untagged VXLAN and VLAN.
Jumbo Frames MTU does not work with DPDK OvS. There is an upstream patch most likely showing up in OvS 2.6 and it cannot be backported due to changes this patch relies upon.

section.title: Reboot requirements
section.para: A reboot of a compute node must be performed when an input model change causes the following:

listitem.para: After the initial site.yml play on a new &ostack; environment
Changes to an existing &ostack; environment that modify the /etc/default/grub file, such as
hugepage allocations
CPU isolation
iommu changes
Changes to a NIC port usage type, such as
moving from DPDK to any combination of PCI-PT and SRIOV
moving from DPDK to kernel based eth driver

section.title: Software configuration
section.para: The input model is processed by the Configuration Processor which eventually results in changes to the OS. There are several files that should be checked to verify the proper settings were applied. In addition, after the inital site.yml play is run all compute nodes must be rebooted in order to pickup changes to the /etc/default/grub file for hugepage reservation, CPU isolation and iommu settings.

listitem.para: hugepages
CPU isolation
that iommu is in passthru mode if the igb_uio driver is in use
using the --dpdk option
core 0 set aside for EAL and kernel to share
cores assigned to PMD drivers, at least two for each DPDK device
verify that memory is reserved with socket-mem option
Once VNETCORE-2509 merges also verify that the umask is 022 and the group is libvirt-qemu
check /etc/dpdk/interfacesf for the correct DPDK devices

section.title: DPDK runtime
section.para: All non-bonded DPDK devices will be added to individual OvS bridges. The bridges will be named br-dpdk0, br-dpdk1, etc. The name of the OvS bridge for bonded DPDK devices will be br-dpdkbond0, br-dpdkbond1, etc.

listitem.para: Verify that ovs-vswitchd is running with
PMD thread(s) are started when a DPDK port is added to an OvS bridge. Verify the port is on the bridge.
A DPDK port cannot be added to an OvS bridge unless it is bound to a driver. Verify that the DPDK port is bound.
Verify that the proper number of hugepages is on the correct NUMA node
or
Verify that the VM and the DPDK PMD threads have both mapped the same hugepage(s)
listitem.screen:
# this will yield 2 process ids, use the 2nd one &prompt.sudo;ps -ef | grep ovs-vswitchd &prompt.sudo;ls -l /proc/PROCESS-ID/fd | grep huge
# if running more than 1 VM you will need to figure out which one to use &prompt.sudo;ps -ef | grep qemu &prompt.sudo;ls -l /proc/PROCESS-ID/fd | grep huge

para.emphasis: VM does not get fixed IP

listitem.para: DPDK Poll Mode drivers (PMD) communicates with the VM by direct access of the VM hugepage. If a VM is not created using hugepages (see ), there is no way for DPDK to communicate with the VM and the VM will never be connected to the network.
It has been observed that the DPDK communication with VM fails if the shared-memory is not disabled in BIOS for DL360 Gen9.

Incorrect input models that do not use the correct DPDK device name or do not use sequential port IDs starting at 0 may leave non-existent devices in the OvS database. While this does not affect proper functionality it may be confusing.
